resource.chars:
thus ranked as <u>Cephalopodous Mollusks</u> in the classification of Lamarck
and Cuvier; which a few others, bearing more resemblance to certain kinds
of Corals, seemed naturally to take their places among <u>Zoophytes</u>
Down to a comparatively recent period, scarcely anything has
been known beyond the external characters presented by these testaceous
or coral-like bodies; their internal organisation has been very
imperfectly examined; of their intimate structure, no attempt at
elucidation has been made; and of the nature of the animals of
which they are the skeletons, the grossest misapprehensions and
errors have prevailed. And though many important steps have been
recently made in this direction, it is obvious that the methods which have
been proposed for the classification of the large number of forms, (apparently
distinct from each other), that have been collected, described, and system-
atised, must be provisional merely. No general foundation has yet
been laid for that due appreciation of the <u>value of characters</u>,
which, as regards every natural group, must be based on
the careful study of its own plan of organisation, and of the
modifications which this may ______
